# Draft:The Clothes in the Wardrobe

The Clothes in the Wardrobe (film)
The Clothes in the Wardrobe is a 1993 British television drama film, produced for the BBC anthology series Screen Two and directed by Waris Hussein. It is an adaptation of Alice Thomas Ellis’s 1987 novel of the same name. The production was first broadcast on BBC2 in 1993 and stars Lena Headey in one of her early leading roles.
Plot
The story follows Margaret, a quiet and unassuming young woman who finds herself reluctantly engaged to a man she does not love. Pressured by family expectations and social convention, she attempts to navigate the complexities of her situation while confiding in her friend and confidante. The narrative explores themes of duty, repression, and the quiet forms of resistance open to women constrained by tradition.
Cast
Lena Headey as Margaret
Padraig O'Loinsigh as Nour(as Padraig Casey)
Britta Smith as Mother Joseph
Catherine Schell as Marie-Claire
Pierre Sioufi as Ahmed
Sherine El Ansari as Gypsy Girl
Julie Walters as Monica
David Threlfall as Syl
Joan Plowright as Mrs. Monro
Jeanne Moreau as Lili
Annabel Burton as Margaret as a Child
Maggie Steed as Mrs. Raffald
John Wood as Robert
Production
The film was produced as part of Screen Two, the BBC’s flagship single-drama strand which ran from 1985 to 1998. Like much of the series, it was shot on location in the United Kingdom and adapted directly from a contemporary literary work.
Reception
While not widely reviewed at the time of its broadcast, the film has since attracted interest for featuring one of Lena Headey’s earliest starring performances, preceding her later prominence in cinema and television.
